Subjective: Bilateral eye irritation, started Tuesday AM in one eye, now affecting both. Sensation of foreign body ('hair or speck of dust'). Eyes are red and swollen. Stuck together in the morning. Pain only on forceful squeezing of eyelids. No vision changes, no photophobia, no significant resting pain, no trauma. No new cosmetics. Not systemically unwell. Social: Has a young daughter; boyfriend is away. Concern for contagion or a more serious condition. Request: Examination and advice on need for drops/antibiotics.
Objective: Eyes: Bilateral conjunctival injection (redness). No foreign body visualized on upper or lower lid eversion. Eyelashes appear normal. Pupils are equally reactive to light.
Assessment: Viral conjunctivitis (inflammation of the surface layer of the eye). No signs of bacterial superinfection at present.
Plan: Reassurance: Explained condition is likely viral and self-resolving, typically within 2 weeks.
Symptomatic relief: Advised over-the-counter artificial tears as needed for irritation.
Hygiene: Advised against rubbing eyes. May cleanse crusted eyelids in the morning with lukewarm tap water and a cotton pad.
Safety Netting: Return immediately for increased pain, significant purulent (pus) discharge, vision changes, or if eyes become more stuck shut.
Follow-up: Return in 2 weeks if symptoms have not resolved.
